III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
1

• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Care Worker is not adequately monitoring health care
services of Youth A to ensure adequate health care is provided.
Investigation Interviews:
I interviewed MDHHS Worker by phone on 05/02/2025. MDHHS
Worker reported/alleged the caregiver of Youth A was not
providing adequate care for Youth A and the agency
monitoring/supervising the case management should have been
aware. MDHHS Worker stated he is in the process of obtaining
medical records of Youth A and would forward that information to
me when it is received. I subsequently received that information
on 05/05/2025 and 05/28/2025.
I interviewed Foster Care Supervisor 2 (FC Supervisor 2) by
phone on 07/10/2025. FC Supervisor 2 stated the agency
assumed case management responsibility in November 2024
when the relative caregiver moved to their area. FC Supervisor 2
referred me to Foster Care Supervisor 1 for additional information.
The information they received at that time indicated the medical
needs for Youth A were being met and the caregiver was directed
to find appropriate medical services providers in the new area.
I interviewed Foster Care Supervisor 1 (FC Supervisor 1) by
phone on 07/10/2025. FC Supervisor 1 stated she had recently
assumed supervisory responsibility for this case on 03/27/2025.
FC Supervisor 1 reported Youth A has been released from the
hospital and is currently placed with a different caregiver. FC
Supervisor 1 stated that she would see that I received any
information requested to assist in the completion of this
investigation. The information/observations at that time indicated
the medical needs for Youth A were being met and the caregiver
was directed to find appropriate medical providers in the new
area, which the caregiver had done.
I interviewed Chief Administrator by phone on 07/11/2025. We
discussed the allegations and the level of
supervision/communication the agency maintained with the
2

caregiver of Youth A, especially as it related to the provision of
medical services. We also discussed the circumstances related to
the change in placement of Youth A and Youth A's sibling. Chief
Administrator stated he would send me the requested information
related to the agency's monitoring/supervision of case
management services. That information was subsequently
received by email on 07/11/2025.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker and FC Supervisor 1 by
phone on 08/07/2025. Foster Care Worker stated she had no
concerns regarding the medical care and treatment being
provided. Foster Care Worker described the caregiver as
cooperative in communicating with Foster Care Worker regarding
Youth A’s medical care. Foster Care Supervisor also expressed
no concerns regarding the medical care of Youth A.
I interviewed Adoption Worker by phone on 08/14/2025.
Adoption Worker stated Youth A appeared to be receiving
appropriate care. Information Adoption Worker received from
medical service providers did not indicate any concerns regarding
the care of Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
Youth A had a medical diagnosis dated 8/2/24 that included
Failure to Thrive, Cerebral Palsey, Disease Nervous System,
Global Develop Delay, and Feeding Intolerance. A diagnosis
dated 4/8/25 added Anemia, Hearing loss, and GERD.
The information received from Chief Administrator by email
indicated the following:
• Bethany Christian Services took over case management on
11/4/24. During the case transfer meeting with the prior
agency, they indicated that medical services would need to
be transferred to care providers in this area due to her
moving. In our initial contacts with the relative she
indicated that Hurley’s had not provided referrals for
services, but indicated she was to find new providers. At
that time the relative indicated she was able to contact a
primary care provider, and an initial visit was already
scheduled for 12/10/24. She indicated that no help was
needed in identifying providers at this time, as she was
already scheduled.
• First contacts with the child and caregiver are recorded by
both foster care and adoption on 11/6/24. Prior to Youth
A's initial well child exam with Bronson on January 13,
foster care staff had four in person home visits with Youth A
3

and the caregiver, and adoption staff had two in person
home visits. Additional contacts including text messages
and phone calls to the caregiver also occurred during this
time. There is documentation in case contacts of the worker
inquiring of the family’s needs and the family did not report
any needs, including with transportation. It was reported
that Youth A's appointment in December was rescheduled
due to a snowstorm on her scheduled date that did not
make travel safe. There was no reported concern for a lack
of transportation on that date or any other date. Her next
scheduled date, January 13, was attended. The statement
she provided at the January 13 appointment about
transportation difficulties was not anything she had shared
with our staff as noted above.
• On 1/28/25 the relative provided names of services
providers to the foster care case manager, who indicated
sharing the information with the agency’s health liaison.
Medical documentation was requested from Bronson on
2/27/25 and documentation was received on 2/28/25.
Documents that were obtained on 2/28/25 indicated full
compliance with visits with the PCP, nutrition, weight
checks, gastroenterology, and PT evaluation.
• March contacts with the family did not identify any needs or
concerns for the welfare of the children.
• As of the March 17 home visit there were no concerns
noted as to the caregiver's ability to meet Youth A's needs,
despite all of the contacts with medical professionals in
January and February (Appt dates of 1/13, 1/24, 1/28, 1/29,
2/ 20, 2/25, 2/27). It appears that it was in March that care
and attendance of appointments for Youth A declined
significantly despite the prior engagement with the
providers and our agency.
• From the time of us accepting the case, communication
and responsiveness of the caregiver to our staff was not
reported to be a concern. She interacted well with staff and
was responsive to communication and appeared engaged.
• Youth A entered the hospital on 4/9/25. The caregiver did
not report this hospitalization to our staff, and we
discovered that she had been hospitalized on 4/16/25 when
we received the MDHHS complaint, this lack of
communication by the caregiver was outside of the norm
based on prior interactions. MDHHS reached out to us via
email requesting information that afternoon and it was
followed shortly after by an email from the MDHHS
supervisor expressing concern about the placement based
on the initial information they had just received from a
4

doctor. Our staff responded immediately supporting the
concern and that we were looking to identify alternative
home(s) for the children and would coordinate with the
MDHHS investigator after his home visit. Due to Youth A
being an MCI ward, MCI staff was included on the initial
email regarding the allegations. As information was shared
by investigators and hospital staff on 4/16/25, Bethany
Christian Services foster care and adoption staff
communicated and agreed with the assessment of concern
for her welfare if returned to the relative caregiver’s home.
This concern is documented in email conversations from
that day that indicate support for removing both children
from the relative caregiver’s home. Due to the caregiver
having a signed intent to adopt, MCI consultation prior to a
move was required and occurred on the same day. MCI
responded that they were assessing the removal need. By
4:59pm that day our on call staff was on their way to
Kalamazoo to pick up the sibling for a medical exam and to
transport to a new placement.
I independently reviewed the case record of Youth A and the
documentation in the case record is consistent with the narrative
reported by Chief Administrator. The record included the following:
• The case record documented Foster Home Visit contact
with Youth A on 11/06/24, 11/27/24, 12/2/24, 12/18/24,
12/23/2024, 1/13/2025, 2/3/2025, 3/17/25, 3/27/2025,
04/24/2025, 05/19/25, 5/23/25, 5/28/2025, 6/06/25, 6/11/25,
and 6/19/25. The contacts all indicated/documented the
child was observed and appeared to be doing well with the
continuation of medical needs being met/provided.
• I reviewed the medical records for Youth A both prior to this
agency's assumption of the case as well as the time
following the agency's assumption of responsibility. There
was no indication in any of these records that would alert
the agency that the caregiver was not providing appropriate
care to meet Youth A's medical needs until the
hospitalization of Youth A on 04/09/2025. The dates of
medical care being provided by Hurley medical personnel
prior to the caregiver’s relocation were 5/15/24, 5/30/24,
6/5/24, 6/6/24, 7/2/24, 7/16/24, 7/22/24, 8/15/24, 8/19/24,
8/21/24, 9/4/24, 9/9/24, 9/18/24, and 9/25/24 with all
including statements of “no concerns”. Visits associated
with new medical providers following the caregiver’s
relocation were documented for 1/13/25, 1/24/25, 1/28/25,
1/29/25, 2/19/25, 2/25/25, 2/27/25, 3/5/25, 3/13/25, 3/18/25,
3/20/25, 3/27/25, 4/3/25, 4/10/25, 4/11/25, 4/13/25, 4/14/25,
5

4/15/25, 4/16/25, 4/29/25, 5/6/25, 5/13/25, 5/20/25. These
documents indicated no concerns regarding the caregiver’s
participation in services for the child.
• A Foster Care Review Board hearing was completed
05/01/2025 as a result of the caregiver appealing the
change in placement of Youth A. The findings of the Foster
Care Review Board were supportive of the caregiver of
Youth A.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as staff interviews, medical
records reviewed, and case record documentation reviewed
indicated the agency staff maintained levels of contact and
communication with Youth A and the relative caregiver of Youth A
consistent with compliance with applicable licensing rules. The
findings of the Foster Care Review Board Hearing are supportive
of this determination/analysis.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
